column4: I just installed Opera but it isn't showing up in my Applications... How can I make a shortcut appear?
Open the menu editor, and add an item.
where is the menu editor
Urm, either right click in the panel by Applications, or it might be over in System > somewhere.
thanks
another problem i have is that I don't even know where i can find an opera icon.  To exec it I have to type opera in terminal
/usr/share/pixmaps I believe.
Let me get into Gnome and check that and the menu editor location.
and since i exec it through terminal, whenever i close the terminal it quits opera, is that normal?
Yes.
i type opera, and it gives me a couple errors saying how my plugins don't work right, and it won't let me type anything else without killing the command/opera
Not sure about the plugins.  I primarily use Firefox.
i want to use FF, but i was trying to upgrade to 1.5 and something went wrong
Also not finding the menu editor where I thought it was, only through right-clicking the Ubuntu icon.
now when i try to run it it says it can't execute child process.... any idea how to revert or fix?
Do you know what?
that will work fine, thanks for that :)
I'd suggest reinstalling 1.07 through apt, which will fix relevant changes to links, remove the 1.5 directory, and start over.
how do i add opera if i don't know where an icon is? :/
ok, how do i do it through apt?  Thanks so much for all this help.  This is exactly how i like learning ubuntu :)
the icon isn't in pixmaps
You can add a menu item without an icon, you'll just need to path to the executable.
Yeah, I'm not finding an icon either.
maybe i could DL one and toss it in therE?
That would work fine.
So.  apt-get remove firefox?
No, that'll break stuff.
sudo apt-get install --reinstall firefox is better.
Let me know if you find a good icon.
i do
well
could i just use the one from the exe?
Which?
http://www.psypress.co.uk/common/images/psypress/rss/opera.gif
i reinstalled firefox and it still gives me the same error: cannot execute child process
cannot execute child process, no such entry or directory
Does it say which process it's looking for?
but for some reason, when i clicked on that link you gave me firefox opened
i think the link in my menu may be looking for 1.5
actually im pretty sure that the problem
That could very well be.  Check what the launcher points to.
how do i tell? through menu editor and look at command?
Yeah.
firefox %u
which firefox
i only had one link to begin with
(Tell me the output of that.)
then someone was going to try and help me switch what the link pointed at i think with some commands i didn't recognize
then when it didn't work
i had no way to make either one work, and now im here
whats the %u mean?
Refers to the current user.
Have you tried 'which firefox' yet?
what do you mean 'which firefox'
it just goes to next line in term
no output
Well isn't that interesting...
indeed
You do have something that works for starting firefox right now, right?  Can you figure out what it's running?
(Just in case that was a simple error, that should have gone into the terminal without the quotes.)
i know :)
Figured.  Thought I'd check though.
right there i right clicked>open in web browser, and FF1.07 came
But do you know the path to the executable?
oh
is there any way to find that through FF?
Not that I'm aware of.
hmm
any other ideas?
Try making some launchers and seeing if any of them work.
You can go ahead and try getting it again, but it would be better if you understood what it was doing now first.
thought so
/usr/lib/mozlila-firefox/firefox
As they said.
Sort of.  It's even more so than a shortcut, but a similar idea.
whats the difference? and how?
and is that where most 'symbolic links' are stored?
sort of like program files? or am i way off
I have symbolic links all over the place, for various purposes.  Essentially with them, anything that point to that spot acts exactly as if it were referencing the file they point to.
so it is a shortcut, but can be used just like the regular executable?
Yeah.
You can do it for non-executables too.  If something's looking for a config file in the wrong spot, throw in a symlink there and it will be happy.
thats cool

one of the things i dont get about unix is that i never know where my programs are.. is that just how it is? in windows everything is in program files (mostly), and on this it seems like they're all over
You can usually 'which programname' to find the executable in the normal paths.
which saves time compared to 'locate' ?
/usr/bin, /usr/sbin, /bin, /sbin for most.
oh, good to know
If it's in one of those, yes.
whats bin stand for, binary?
Yeah.
Which is a little silly, because it's a computer, and everything's binary, but that's what they call it.
this isn't a problem at all, but when i start opera it says 'couldn't start plug-in executable "operamotifwrapper". please install motif'
i searched for motif in the package manager and thought i installed it (or something that said it helped install motif apps), but i still get it, any idea?
Plugin link, perhaps?
